titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George Clarke papers, 1863-1864
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, September 2018

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Includes correspondence from J.J. Alvord to George Clarke, a resident of Wyandotte, Wayne County, Michigan. The letters discuss 1863 elections; criticism of George Brinton McClellan; the gubernatorial and congressional elections in Michigan; and candidates Judge Edwards of Tuscola County, William A. Horward, Jacob M. Howard, and Fernando C. Beaman.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: George Clarke Papers, 1863-1864, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, September 2018.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: George Clarke was a resident of Wyandotte, Wayne County, Michigan. J.J. Alvord was a clerk in the Indian Office in Washington, D.C; and a delegate from Wayne County to the state constitutional convention in 1850.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence from J.J. Alvord to George Clarke, a resident of Wyandotte, Wayne County, Michigan. The letters discuss 1863 elections; criticism of George Brinton McClellan; the gubernatorial and congressional elections in Michigan; and candidates Judge Edwards of Tuscola County, William A. Horward, Jacob M. Howard, and Fernando C. Beaman.
